The 'Spotted Owl' (Strix occidentalis) is a species of true owl. It is a
resident species of old-growth forests in western North America, where it nests
in tree holes, old bird of prey nests, or rock crevices. Nests can be between
high and usually contain two eggs (though some will contain as many as four). It
is a nocturnal owl, which feeds on small mammals and birds.

This owl has a length of 43 cm (17 inches), a wingspan of , and a
weight of around . Its eggs are a little over long, and are white and smooth
with a slightly grainy texture. The female sits on the eggs and cares for the
young, while the male provides food for them. Juvenile Spotted Owls have an
average survival rate of 11%, with an average birth rate of 0.58 owls per pair.

The Spotted Owl is similar in appearance to the Barred Owl but has cross-shaped
markings on the underparts, whereas the Barred Owl is alternately barred on the
breast and streaked on the belly. Barred Owls are larger and grayer than Spotted
Owls. In recent years the California and Northern subspecies of Spotted Owl have
been displaced by Barred Owls, which are more aggressive, have a broader diet
and occur in more varied habitats. {{Cite journal |last
=Welch|first =Craig|last2 =Braasch|first2 =Gary |date =January 2009|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/The-Spotted-Owls-New-
Nemesis.html |title =The Spotted Owl's New Nemesis |periodical
=Smithsonian|volume =39|issue =10|pages =62â67 }} Though the two species
may hybridize in areas where displacement is occurring, they are quite
genetically distinct, for example, differing 13.9% in certain gene
sequences.
